recommendations: Consider a CT Chest with Angiography for detailed assessment of the thoracic aorta and vascular structures given the primary diagnosis.
Ensure adequate hydration prior to and following contrast administration to mitigate potential renal insult.
Monitor hemodynamic status closely, particularly blood pressure, during and after contrast administration.
Explore non-contrast imaging options if contrast administration is deemed too high risk given the severe hypotension.
rationale: Primary diagnosis of 'Injury to thoracic aorta' directly aligns with the indications for CT Chest Angiography.
Severe hypotension (MAP 49.3 mmHg) is a significant risk factor for contrast-induced nephropathy and requires careful consideration of hydration and contrast protocols.
Stage 1 CKD does not preclude contrast use, but the hemodynamic instability warrants enhanced vigilance and mitigation strategies.
The trauma protocol is less specific to the aortic injury, while CT Angiography is optimized for vascular assessment.

protocol_selection.name: CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE)
protocol_selection.description: CT angiography timed for pulmonary arterial phase (6–13 sec post-contrast) to evaluate pulmonary arteries for embolism.
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Weight-based; ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast (300 mg I/mL); follow ACR Manual.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Ensure contrast-to-eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min); if eGFR <30, consider non-contrast alternatives or weigh risks carefully.

protocol_selection.name: Trauma CT — Chest, Abdomen & Pelvis with Contrast
protocol_selection.description: Contrast CT of torso with trauma-focused reformats; may include delayed images as needed.
protocol_selection.contrast_timing: Portal venous phase, possible delayed imaging to assess hemorrhage.
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Standard contrast dose; trauma protocols may include split bolus techniques.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Minimize field-of-view and dose; use alternative imaging if stable and renal risk high.
